III NEE
BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 8, 1915.

VOL. XIX, NO. 16.

MUSICAL CLUBS OPEN

1ER

SEASON

Give Successful Performance in Westminster After Tryout at Phipps Clinic.
McCoy Hall Concert Tuesday.

The University Musical Clubs
officially opened their season last
Friday night at Westminster, where
they gave a concert at Alumni Hall
of Western Maryland College. This
was the first appearance of our
Musical Clubs in this town.
Twenty-eight men who were selected to make the trip left Union
Station at two o'clock Friday afternoon and arrived at Westminster
an hour and a half later in a drizzling rain.
After the usual preliminaries of
registering at the hotel and giving Hopkins yells at suitable points
in the town, the musicians held a
short, snappy rehearsal at Alumni
Hall.
By eight o'clock, the time scheduled for the concert, it was raining hard, and the men experienced
some difficulty in traversing the distance of one mile from the hotel to
the college grounds.
The concert was a distinct success in nearly every particular. Both
the Glee and Instrumental Clubs
were repeatedly called upon for encores, and the soloists carried off
the usual honors. The Glee Club
made a decided hit with "Drink to
Me Only With Thine Eyes," and
the Instrumental Club was best
heard in the selections from "Sari"
and "High Jinks."
A feature of the concert was the
introduction of a humorous sketch,
announced as the "Bostadelphia
Symphony Band," which was given
by six of the comedians of the
Club, and which elicited more than
the usual share of applause. This
stunt has been worked up by members of the Club and since it is
really funny, promises to be *a feature of future programs.
The quartet sang catchy negro
melodies which have within the
past few months become very popular and which were very well received by the Westminster audience.
The musicians left Westminster
for Baltimore Saturday morning
feeling much elated at their success in the opening concert of the
season.
A tryout concert was held previous to the Westminster engagement on Wednesday night at the
Phipps Clinic of the Johns Hopkins Hospital. This affair, while
not as eminently successful as the
Westminster concert, was carried
through in a manner which seemed
to predict the coming success of
Friday night. After the concert
the musicians were served with re(('ontinued on Page 8, col. 2)

"ED" HOOPER BASEBALL COACH
Was Reappointed for Fourth Season
at Meeting of Athletic Board.
Practice to Begin Soon.

TO KEEP A RECORD OF "H" MEN

FOOTBALL SCHEDULE ANNOUNCED

Athletic Honor Roll of Those Who Have
Received Letter to Be Compiled.
Dr. G.L. Radcliffe's Idea.

St. Johns Game to Come Before Thanksgiving—Selection of Coach to Be
Made in the Near Future.

At the January meeting of the
Athletic Association, the president
appointed a committee to look into
the matter of making a book that
will contain the autographs or,
when these cannot be obtained, the
names of the Hopkins men who
have made "H's." A meeting of the
committee was held a few days ago
at the office of Dr. G. L. Radcliffe,
the alumni member of the committee and the originator of the idea
of an "H" book.
As outlined by Dr. Radcliffe, the
records of the "H's" awarded are
to be entered in a substantial book,
which is to be kept in the Trophy
Room. This will give freshmen
and others a chance to find out who
are on the athletic honor roll at the
University.
Since the meeting of the committee many of the Hopkins records
have been searched and the names
of about two hundred "H" men
have been secured. At the meeting
of the Athletic Board, held on February 1, the report of the "H" Committee was accepted and the Board
recommended that the work on the
proposed book be continued.
Owing to the fact that many of
the sources of the material for this
book are incomplete, the "H"
Committee takes the opportunity
through the courtesy of THE NEwsLETTER to ask those of the alumni
who have "H's" to communicate
with the committee, giving their
names and the names of any other
"H" men who were on the teams
at the time that their "H" was
awarded. This will aid the committee very much in getting up the
book. It has not yet been decided
whether the book shall be arranged
alphabetically or by years.
The committee at work on this
book consists of Dr. G. L. Radcliffe, C. T. Uhler and W. S. Merrick. Anyone who has received an
"H" is- requested to send his name
to either W. S. Merrick, 'is, or
C. I. Uhler, '15, Johns Hopkins
University.

The football schedule for next
fall, which was officialy announced
last week by Graduate Manager
George E. Dorsey and Manager
Charlie Tinges, is as follows:
October 9—Randolph-Macon at
Homewood.
October i6—Western Maryland
at Homewood.
October 23—Washington College
at Homewood.
October 30—S war thmo re at
Homewood.
November 6—G ettvsburg at
Homewood.
November 13—H aver ford at
Haverford.
November 20 — St. John's at
Homewood.
November 25—Maryland Aggies
at Homewood.
Randolph-Macon, the opening opponent, has not played the Black
and Blue for three years, the last
game having resulted in a 26-to-o
victory for the local 'Varsity.
Washington College and Western
Maryland occupy their usual positions on the early season schedule,
and following them are three Pennsylvania teams—Swarthmore, Gettysburg and Haverford.
The St. John's game was shifted
from Thanksgiving Day to Saturday, November 20, and will not be
the closing contest of the season.
The Aggies, an eleven which seems
to be a hard early-season proposition for Hopkins, have been given
the wind-up location.
With the schedule completed, the
Hopkins management will give its
attention to the selection of a coach.
Jack Cates, who handled the squad
for a season and a half, was not
offered the position, because the
football advisers want a man who
will devote all his time to coaching.
This, of course, Oates is unable to
do. An excellent prospect, a coach
of fame in the East, was approached, but before he could put
his pen to a contract he received an
attractive business position in another city, which precluded the pos-

E. E. Hooper was reappointed
coach of the 'Varsity baseball team
at a meeting of the Athletic Board
Monday afternoon in the Trophy
Room. This season will be his
fourth as tutor of the nine.
Coach Hooper has always felt a
close interest in the diamond sport
at Hopkins, and when the Athletic
Association recognized baseball five
years ago he was chosen to take
charge of the squad. The year following, Coach Harlan handled both
baseball and football. Mr. Hooper
was recalled in 1913 and reappointed in 1914.
He has had a wide experience
in baseball, and was manager of
the Lancaster team of the Tri-State
League during the latter part of
last season. At the beginning of
the year he had been signed by the
Pittsburgh team of the Federal
League, but did not report. He
joined the York Tri-State team, going to Lancaster during June. He
has been promised a position on the
Lancaster team after he has finished
the season with the 'Varsity. He
is a Baltimorean and played on the
Oriole team of
'the International
League several seasons ago.
Candidates for the 'Varsity will
be called to an organization meeting, which will probably be held
next week. Announcements of the
meeting will be posted on the bulletin boards. Practices will begin immediately thereafter.
Coach Hooper will have the men
at work in the cage for a few
weeks' limbering up and then the
squad will move to Homewood.
The cage practice has been cut in
half this year because of the danger
of the work in the small enclosure.
When twenty balls are being thrown
about and several batsmen are lining out hits to infield candidates,
the practice becomes more of the
nature of keeping from being hit
than of learning how to play baseball.
Capt. Pete Porter has discovered
several players with experience at
the Medical School, and a number
of promising men have entered the
college this year. These and last
year's players, together with the
"green material" which Coach
Hooper wants to have in his "school
of instruction," will compose a
rather well-balanced squad.
This year's schedule is almost
complete. Three dates are yet to be
filled, and correspondence covering
them is out. As soon as the dates
are closed the schedule will be announced.

Bob Layfield is still holding on
to life with the gritty determination
and unquenchable optimism which
from the first have characterized his
fight for recovery. Now that some
hope is entertained for his. success
in pulling through, he is more than
ever determined to get well.
On February 4 he received hundreds of postcards from friends and
strangers who are interested in his
case. The cards were sent as a
surprise, which had been planned
by the Sunshine Society of Wilmington. This society sent cards
to all the groups of people who are
interested in Bob's battle, asking
them to join in sending him as many
cards as possible. The surprise was
a distinct success; Bob was pleased
mightily at the manifestations of
good-will which came pouring in
from all sides.
Bob is now in his own home.
Last Monday he was deemed strong
enough to be moved from the Delaware Hospital and was, in accordance with his wishes, brought back
to his home for the first time since
last November.
There has been no change in his
general condition; no evil effects
have resulted from the removal to
his home, and his physicians still say
that there is a very slight chance
for his recovery.
Bob's parents are very optimistic;
it is this atmosphere of optimism
which has helped Bob in the steadfast courage which he is showing.
The postals also have helped; they
have given Bob a tangible proof of
the multitude of his friends who
are anxiously hoping for and looking forward to a time when he may
be with them again.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 8, 1915.
DEBATERS HAVE BUSY SESSION

CHOOSE NEW ASSISTANT COACH
Plans for Coming Season Drawn Up.
Date for Tryouts Announced--A. S.
Niles, Jr., Elected Manager.

A meeting of the Debating Council was held at five o'clock Monday afternoon, and attention was
given to matters connected with the
inter-'Varsity debates which will
take place on April 25.
The first business before the
Council was the election of a team
manager for the present season,
and Alfred S. Niles, Jr., was unanimously chosen for the position.
After the report of last year's manager had been read, various methods of raising money to meet expenses were discussed, particularly
the possibility of securing a yearly
allowance from the general athletic
fund, or of devoting to the use of
the debating teams a part of the income from the Adams bequest. The
Council is not concerned over the
prospects for this season, but is
anxious to put the 'Varsity debating of the future on a sound financial basis.
As the Virginia debaters have
written to the Hopkins Council
suggesting a further limitation of
the subject or a definition of some
of the terms involved, it was decided that the North Carolina Society should be consulted, in order
that the will of the majority might
be ascertained. The possible ambiguity of the question was made
evident in the senior-junior debate.
It is, of course, desirable that any
such vagueness should be avoided,
and the Hopkins Council is anxious
to do as much as possible to bring
about this end.
The tryouts for the Hopkins
teams which will defend the affirmative and negative of the question: "Resolved, That a Policy of
Colonial Expansion Is Desirable for
the Modern State," in North Carolina and Virginia, respectively, will
be held in the assembly hall at one
o'clock Wednesday. All undergraduates are eligible to take part in the
debates, and it is hoped that the
places on the teams will be hotly
contested. Honorary debating "H's"
will be awarded to the members of
victorious teams, including the alternates and advisers.
The final matter brought up for
discussion at the meeting of the
Council was the prospect of holding the annual Peace Contest this
year. There is some doubt as to
the possibility of obtaining the appropriation that has usually been
offered as a prize in this contest,
however, and consequently it seems
somewhat improbable that Hopkins
orators will be given this opportunity of matching their eloquence with
that of representatives of other institutions.

SPECIAL OFFER to Professors and Students.

LACROSSE COMMITTEE WILL

With the departure of Julian
Marshall for London, where he expects to join the British army, the
lacrosse team loses a valuable and
energetic assistant coach.
Just who will be Mr. Marshall's
successor is impossible to state at
the present time. The Lacrosse
Committee will make a selection and
recommend their choice to the Athletic Board. The committee is composed of Dr. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Graduate Manager George Dorsey, Captain Tom Troxell, Manager
Hiram Woodward and the three advisers to the team. Nothing has
been done by the committee toward
selecting Mr. Marshall's successor.
The lacrosse squad is anxiously
awaiting the time when practice can
be held outdoors. This depends entirely on how soon the weather conditions will permit. Usually the
squad is able to abandon the cage
during the early part of March.
The first practices outdoors are held
on the Country School field behind
the old Carroll Mansion, so as not
to injure the Homewood grounds
during the early spring when the
soil is soft.
Captain Troxell reports that his
squad is getting along as well as
can be expected, with the new men
rapidly becoming acquainted with
the fundamentals of the game. The
close defense has the most to learn,
due to the fact that this department
is composed of new men this year.
Among the new men who are
showing up well are: F. Sutton,
Hoffman, A. Wolfe, D. Woodward,
Evans, Boyce and Wilson.
When the indoor track season is
over the squad will be strengthened
by the addition of several members
of the track squad.

Freshman Basket Ball Teams Reorganize.

Now that the preliminary games
have been played, the freshman basket ball teams have been reorganized
into a new league. This league will
be composed of four teams, made
up of players picked from the best
of the former teams. Games will
be played on Monday and Wednesday afternoons at 5.30 o'clock.
The following have been elected
to captain the various teams: Team
No. 1, Rosenau ; Team No. 2, Levy;
Team No. 3, Jacobson; Team No.
4, Egerton.
The score of the freshman gymnasium contest is running very
close. The Blues, led by Captain
Egerton, have 66 points against the
62 which have been scored by the
Whites, captained by Edel.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 8, 1915.
The Musical Clubs.

In their recent concert at Western Maryland College, the Musical
Clubs clearly gave evidence of the
fact that they are this year starting
out on their season with the determination to achieve success in all
of their undertakings. The men
began their work last October under an entirely new form of management, and although they suffered
under the burden of a poor reputation, which had been made by past
clubs, by dint of hard work at frequent rehearsals they pulled themselves together and rounded into
condition for their opening concert
by the end of January.
Results have thus far shown that
their efforts have not been in vain.
Owing to the consistent support
given by the members after the reorganization, and to the redoubled
efforts of the officers, both the Instrumental and Glee clubs have
been highly successful in the concerts thus far given, and bid fair
to surpass anything of the kind that
has ever existed at Hopkins before
they close their season.
After the concert at Westminster,
Prof. William R. -McDaniel, of
Western Maryland College, spoke
to President Baker, of the Clubs,
saying that the men were distinctly
to be congratulated on the dignity
with which they carried themselves
throughout their concert and their
stay in Westminster, and on the
excellent concert they gave. He
emphasized the point that the success of the Clubs was the more remarkable when one considers the
fact that there is no dormitory life
at Johns Hopkins and that hence
the men must come together from

The Swimming Team.

The recent success of the newly
organized independent swimming
team in its two local meets brings
to our attention the awakening of
interest in a new activity at Hopkins. Although the teams defeated
so far have not been of a calibre
which might be expected of a college like Johns Hopkins, the steady
improvement which has been shown
and the energy which the management has evinced in giving the team
a start must be recognized as an
important step in the direction of
establishing the permanency of the
activity.
Especial credit is due Captain
Rowland and Manager Richardson
for their untiring efforts to make
the team a success; the prompt response of able men and the willingness of other teams to arrange
meets seems to point out that the
swimmers have formed an organization which is here to stay. The
team is to be congratulated on its
ability, its energy and its determination to make good.
Marshall Lands in England.

Julian H. M arshall, who sailed
a week ago on the Lusitania to join
the English army, has cabled to his
relat:ves in Baltimore that he has
arrived safely and intends to lose no
time in making immediate preparation to start out on his training
work.
Mr. Marshall will visit his relatives in England for a short time,
after which he will enter an officers'
training school, where he vill receive the training necessary to prepare him for active service as a commissioned officer in the British army.
He is very enthusiastic in his determination to see service as soon
as possible, and will therefore do
everything he can to obtain his
commission at the earliest opportunity.

ENGINEERING SOCIETY HOLDS
IMPORTANT BUSINESS MEETING

FROM THE ALUMNI MAGAZINE I

The January edition of the Alumni allagazine contains an article by
Professor Willoughby in which he
briefly discusses the problem of a
law school at Hopkins.
Dr. Willoughby favors the establishment of a law school which will
rank as high in the field of legal
instruction as the Medical School
does in the field of medical research
and teaching, and which will combine a university school of jurisprudence and a professional school
of law.
He emphasizes that provision
should be made for the study of
law, not simply as an art, but as
a science and as a philosophy.
* * *
In this edition of the magazine
there is a most interesting editorial
comment on the result of this year's
football season. This editorial states
that, considering the material at
hand, the coaching and the support
given the team by the student body,
more victories for Hopkins should
have resulted. The failure to win
is attributed to the fact that not
enough time was available to the
players for adequate practice, as so
much of their time was taken up
by University work. High praise,
however, is given to several players, particularly Captain Wilkinson
and Bob Hodman, who is called
a "football hero."
* * *

alumnus appeals for a chapel at

Two papers of especial interest
were presented at the regular
monthly meeting of the Engineering Society at Homewood last Friday.
The first was by J. M. Lednum,
graduate, on "Scientific Management." Mr. Lednum spoke of the
principles of Taylor and of Thompson, and told how these principles
were applied to the laying of the
sewerage system of Guilford. He
was employed on this work last
summer and gave several graphic
illustrations of practical scientific
management.
Abram Tobias was the second
speaker. His subject was hydroelectric development. After discussing the principles of location,
choice of turbines and generators,
and of transmission of large
amounts of electric energy, he
showed how these principles were
brought out in the construction of
the plant on the Patapsco at Ilchester, Md.
After a discussion ot the topics
presented by the speakers, in which
the members took part, the matter
of the formation of a collegiate
branch of the American Society of
Mechanical Engineers here at Hopkills was brought up by Dr. C. C.
Thomas, professor of mechanical
engineering. His proposition was
well received and was referred to
the Executive Committee slf the
Society with instructions to report
in the near future.
The attendance was very good.
Several of the engineering faculty
were present.
The next meeting will be held
March 5, at which time Messrs.
Evitt and Hutton will speak.

All the classes are eagerly looking forward to the annual class banquets, scheduled to come off this
month. These banquets will be of
great importance, especially to the
two lower classes, for "banquet
time" has always been a big event
for these two classes.
This year the freshmen are preparing to make their banquet a
howling success. The committee in
charge, consisting of Nelson, chairman; Egerton and Wolfe, are mapping out a line of campaign which
is to outdo any previous banquet of
like nature.
"Speakers will be had and many
distinguished men, who are enrolled
in the Class of 1918, will hold forth
to their less informed hearers," says
a member of the 1918 Committee.
The sophomores have also many
exciting plans laid. The sophomore
committee consists of Gorman, Fulton and Bin ford, and they have already undertaken the grave and
serious duties laid upon their shoulders. The seniors and juniors, upon
whom rest the dignity and prestige
of the University, have decided that
while their entertainments will be
joyous occasions, they will leave the
horse-play to the lower classes.
As a result of these deep-laid
schemes, the Johns Hopkins University and the City of Baltimore
will certainly witness some "gay
doings" this month.
The senior banquet committee
has not definitely chosen a date, but
the "feed" probably will be held on
the night of February 22 or 24.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 8, 1915.

VOL. XIX, NO. 16.

MUSICAL CLUBS OPEN

1ER

SEASON

Give Successful Performance in Westminster After Tryout at Phipps Clinic.
McCoy Hall Concert Tuesday.

The University Musical Clubs
officially opened their season last
Friday night at Westminster, where
they gave a concert at Alumni Hall
of Western Maryland College. This
was the first appearance of our
Musical Clubs in this town.
Twenty-eight men who were selected to make the trip left Union
Station at two o'clock Friday afternoon and arrived at Westminster
an hour and a half later in a drizzling rain.
After the usual preliminaries of
registering at the hotel and giving Hopkins yells at suitable points
in the town, the musicians held a
short, snappy rehearsal at Alumni
Hall.
By eight o'clock, the time scheduled for the concert, it was raining hard, and the men experienced
some difficulty in traversing the distance of one mile from the hotel to
the college grounds.
The concert was a distinct success in nearly every particular. Both
the Glee and Instrumental Clubs
were repeatedly called upon for encores, and the soloists carried off
the usual honors. The Glee Club
made a decided hit with "Drink to
Me Only With Thine Eyes," and
the Instrumental Club was best
heard in the selections from "Sari"
and "High Jinks."
A feature of the concert was the
introduction of a humorous sketch,
announced as the "Bostadelphia
Symphony Band," which was given
by six of the comedians of the
Club, and which elicited more than
the usual share of applause. This
stunt has been worked up by members of the Club and since it is
really funny, promises to be *a feature of future programs.
The quartet sang catchy negro
melodies which have within the
past few months become very popular and which were very well received by the Westminster audience.
The musicians left Westminster
for Baltimore Saturday morning
feeling much elated at their success in the opening concert of the
season.
A tryout concert was held previous to the Westminster engagement on Wednesday night at the
Phipps Clinic of the Johns Hopkins Hospital. This affair, while
not as eminently successful as the
Westminster concert, was carried
through in a manner which seemed
to predict the coming success of
Friday night. After the concert
the musicians were served with re(('ontinued on Page 8, col. 2)

St. Johns Game to Come Before Thanksgiving—Selection of Coach to Be

At the January meeting of the
Athletic Association, the president
appointed a committee to look into
the matter of making a book that
will contain the autographs or,
when these cannot be obtained, the
names of the Hopkins men who
have made "H's." A meeting of the
committee was held a few days ago
at the office of Dr. G. L. Radcliffe,
the alumni member of the committee and the originator of the idea
of an "H" book.
As outlined by Dr. Radcliffe, the
records of the "H's" awarded are
to be entered in a substantial book,
which is to be kept in the Trophy
Room. This will give freshmen
and others a chance to find out who
are on the athletic honor roll at the
University.
Since the meeting of the committee many of the Hopkins records
have been searched and the names
of about two hundred "H" men
have been secured. At the meeting
of the Athletic Board, held on February 1, the report of the "H" Committee was accepted and the Board
recommended that the work on the
proposed book be continued.
Owing to the fact that many of
the sources of the material for this
book are incomplete, the "H"
Committee takes the opportunity
through the courtesy of THE NEwsLETTER to ask those of the alumni
who have "H's" to communicate
with the committee, giving their
names and the names of any other
"H" men who were on the teams
at the time that their "H" was
awarded. This will aid the committee very much in getting up the
book. It has not yet been decided
whether the book shall be arranged
alphabetically or by years.
The committee at work on this
book consists of Dr. G. L. Radcliffe, C. T. Uhler and W. S. Merrick. Anyone who has received an
"H" is- requested to send his name
to either W. S. Merrick, 'is, or
C. I. Uhler, '15, Johns Hopkins
University.

E. E. Hooper was reappointed
coach of the 'Varsity baseball team
at a meeting of the Athletic Board
Monday afternoon in the Trophy
Room. This season will be his
fourth as tutor of the nine.
Coach Hooper has always felt a
close interest in the diamond sport
at Hopkins, and when the Athletic
Association recognized baseball five
years ago he was chosen to take
charge of the squad. The year following, Coach Harlan handled both
baseball and football. Mr. Hooper
was recalled in 1913 and reappointed in 1914.
He has had a wide experience
in baseball, and was manager of
the Lancaster team of the Tri-State
League during the latter part of
last season. At the beginning of
the year he had been signed by the
Pittsburgh team of the Federal
League, but did not report. He
joined the York Tri-State team, going to Lancaster during June. He
has been promised a position on the
Lancaster team after he has finished
the season with the 'Varsity. He
is a Baltimorean and played on the
Oriole team of
'the International
League several seasons ago.
Candidates for the 'Varsity will
be called to an organization meeting, which will probably be held
next week. Announcements of the
meeting will be posted on the bulletin boards. Practices will begin immediately thereafter.
Coach Hooper will have the men
at work in the cage for a few
weeks' limbering up and then the
squad will move to Homewood.
The cage practice has been cut in
half this year because of the danger
of the work in the small enclosure.
When twenty balls are being thrown
about and several batsmen are lining out hits to infield candidates,
the practice becomes more of the
nature of keeping from being hit
than of learning how to play baseball.
Capt. Pete Porter has discovered
several players with experience at
the Medical School, and a number
of promising men have entered the
college this year. These and last
year's players, together with the
"green material" which Coach
Hooper wants to have in his "school
of instruction," will compose a
rather well-balanced squad.
This year's schedule is almost
complete. Three dates are yet to be
filled, and correspondence covering
them is out. As soon as the dates
are closed the schedule will be announced.

Bob Layfield is still holding on
to life with the gritty determination
and unquenchable optimism which
from the first have characterized his
fight for recovery. Now that some
hope is entertained for his. success
in pulling through, he is more than
ever determined to get well.
On February 4 he received hundreds of postcards from friends and
strangers who are interested in his
case. The cards were sent as a
surprise, which had been planned
by the Sunshine Society of Wilmington. This society sent cards
to all the groups of people who are
interested in Bob's battle, asking
them to join in sending him as many
cards as possible. The surprise was
a distinct success; Bob was pleased
mightily at the manifestations of
good-will which came pouring in
from all sides.
Bob is now in his own home.
Last Monday he was deemed strong
enough to be moved from the Delaware Hospital and was, in accordance with his wishes, brought back
to his home for the first time since
last November.
There has been no change in his
general condition; no evil effects
have resulted from the removal to
his home, and his physicians still say
that there is a very slight chance
for his recovery.
Bob's parents are very optimistic;
it is this atmosphere of optimism
which has helped Bob in the steadfast courage which he is showing.
The postals also have helped; they
have given Bob a tangible proof of
the multitude of his friends who
are anxiously hoping for and looking forward to a time when he may
be with them again.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 8, 1915.
DEBATERS HAVE BUSY SESSION

CHOOSE NEW ASSISTANT COACH
Plans for Coming Season Drawn Up.
Date for Tryouts Announced--A. S.
Niles, Jr., Elected Manager.

A meeting of the Debating Council was held at five o'clock Monday afternoon, and attention was
given to matters connected with the
inter-'Varsity debates which will
take place on April 25.
The first business before the
Council was the election of a team
manager for the present season,
and Alfred S. Niles, Jr., was unanimously chosen for the position.
After the report of last year's manager had been read, various methods of raising money to meet expenses were discussed, particularly
the possibility of securing a yearly
allowance from the general athletic
fund, or of devoting to the use of
the debating teams a part of the income from the Adams bequest. The
Council is not concerned over the
prospects for this season, but is
anxious to put the 'Varsity debating of the future on a sound financial basis.
As the Virginia debaters have
written to the Hopkins Council
suggesting a further limitation of
the subject or a definition of some
of the terms involved, it was decided that the North Carolina Society should be consulted, in order
that the will of the majority might
be ascertained. The possible ambiguity of the question was made
evident in the senior-junior debate.
It is, of course, desirable that any
such vagueness should be avoided,
and the Hopkins Council is anxious
to do as much as possible to bring
about this end.
The tryouts for the Hopkins
teams which will defend the affirmative and negative of the question: "Resolved, That a Policy of
Colonial Expansion Is Desirable for
the Modern State," in North Carolina and Virginia, respectively, will
be held in the assembly hall at one
o'clock Wednesday. All undergraduates are eligible to take part in the
debates, and it is hoped that the
places on the teams will be hotly
contested. Honorary debating "H's"
will be awarded to the members of
victorious teams, including the alternates and advisers.
The final matter brought up for
discussion at the meeting of the
Council was the prospect of holding the annual Peace Contest this
year. There is some doubt as to
the possibility of obtaining the appropriation that has usually been
offered as a prize in this contest,
however, and consequently it seems
somewhat improbable that Hopkins
orators will be given this opportunity of matching their eloquence with
that of representatives of other institutions.

SPECIAL OFFER to Professors and Students.

LACROSSE COMMITTEE WILL

With the departure of Julian
Marshall for London, where he expects to join the British army, the
lacrosse team loses a valuable and
energetic assistant coach.
Just who will be Mr. Marshall's
successor is impossible to state at
the present time. The Lacrosse
Committee will make a selection and
recommend their choice to the Athletic Board. The committee is composed of Dr. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Graduate Manager George Dorsey, Captain Tom Troxell, Manager
Hiram Woodward and the three advisers to the team. Nothing has
been done by the committee toward
selecting Mr. Marshall's successor.
The lacrosse squad is anxiously
awaiting the time when practice can
be held outdoors. This depends entirely on how soon the weather conditions will permit. Usually the
squad is able to abandon the cage
during the early part of March.
The first practices outdoors are held
on the Country School field behind
the old Carroll Mansion, so as not
to injure the Homewood grounds
during the early spring when the
soil is soft.
Captain Troxell reports that his
squad is getting along as well as
can be expected, with the new men
rapidly becoming acquainted with
the fundamentals of the game. The
close defense has the most to learn,
due to the fact that this department
is composed of new men this year.
Among the new men who are
showing up well are: F. Sutton,
Hoffman, A. Wolfe, D. Woodward,
Evans, Boyce and Wilson.
When the indoor track season is
over the squad will be strengthened
by the addition of several members
of the track squad.

have been played, the freshman basket ball teams have been reorganized

be composed of four teams, made

to captain the various teams: Team
No. 1, Rosenau ; Team No. 2, Levy;
Team No. 3, Jacobson; Team No.
4, Egerton.
The score of the freshman gymnasium contest is running very
close. The Blues, led by Captain
Egerton, have 66 points against the
62 which have been scored by the
Whites, captained by Edel.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 8, 1915.
The Musical Clubs.

In their recent concert at Western Maryland College, the Musical
Clubs clearly gave evidence of the
fact that they are this year starting
out on their season with the determination to achieve success in all
of their undertakings. The men
began their work last October under an entirely new form of management, and although they suffered
under the burden of a poor reputation, which had been made by past
clubs, by dint of hard work at frequent rehearsals they pulled themselves together and rounded into
condition for their opening concert
by the end of January.
Results have thus far shown that
their efforts have not been in vain.
Owing to the consistent support
given by the members after the reorganization, and to the redoubled
efforts of the officers, both the Instrumental and Glee clubs have
been highly successful in the concerts thus far given, and bid fair
to surpass anything of the kind that
has ever existed at Hopkins before
they close their season.
After the concert at Westminster,
Prof. William R. -McDaniel, of
Western Maryland College, spoke
to President Baker, of the Clubs,
saying that the men were distinctly
to be congratulated on the dignity
with which they carried themselves
throughout their concert and their
stay in Westminster, and on the
excellent concert they gave. He
emphasized the point that the success of the Clubs was the more remarkable when one considers the
fact that there is no dormitory life
at Johns Hopkins and that hence
the men must come together from

The Swimming Team.

The recent success of the newly
organized independent swimming
team in its two local meets brings
to our attention the awakening of
interest in a new activity at Hopkins. Although the teams defeated
so far have not been of a calibre
which might be expected of a college like Johns Hopkins, the steady
improvement which has been shown
and the energy which the management has evinced in giving the team
a start must be recognized as an
important step in the direction of
establishing the permanency of the
activity.
Especial credit is due Captain
Rowland and Manager Richardson
for their untiring efforts to make
the team a success; the prompt response of able men and the willingness of other teams to arrange
meets seems to point out that the
swimmers have formed an organization which is here to stay. The
team is to be congratulated on its
ability, its energy and its determination to make good.
Marshall Lands in England.

Julian H. M arshall, who sailed
a week ago on the Lusitania to join
the English army, has cabled to his
relat:ves in Baltimore that he has
arrived safely and intends to lose no
time in making immediate preparation to start out on his training
work.
Mr. Marshall will visit his relatives in England for a short time,
after which he will enter an officers'
training school, where he vill receive the training necessary to prepare him for active service as a commissioned officer in the British army.
He is very enthusiastic in his determination to see service as soon
as possible, and will therefore do
everything he can to obtain his
commission at the earliest opportunity.

ENGINEERING SOCIETY HOLDS
IMPORTANT BUSINESS MEETING

FROM THE ALUMNI MAGAZINE I

The January edition of the Alumni allagazine contains an article by
Professor Willoughby in which he
briefly discusses the problem of a
law school at Hopkins.
Dr. Willoughby favors the establishment of a law school which will
rank as high in the field of legal
instruction as the Medical School
does in the field of medical research
and teaching, and which will combine a university school of jurisprudence and a professional school
of law.
He emphasizes that provision
should be made for the study of
law, not simply as an art, but as
a science and as a philosophy.
* * *
In this edition of the magazine
there is a most interesting editorial
comment on the result of this year's
football season. This editorial states
that, considering the material at
hand, the coaching and the support
given the team by the student body,
more victories for Hopkins should
have resulted. The failure to win
is attributed to the fact that not
enough time was available to the
players for adequate practice, as so
much of their time was taken up
by University work. High praise,
however, is given to several players, particularly Captain Wilkinson
and Bob Hodman, who is called
a "football hero."
* * *

alumnus appeals for a chapel at
Homewood, not merely for the religious advantages to be derived,
but rather for the purpose of stimulating college spirit. This alumnus suggests that the president of
the University, the Dean or some
other member of the faculty should
officiate at the chapel service and

Two papers of especial interest
were presented at the regular
monthly meeting of the Engineering Society at Homewood last Friday.
The first was by J. M. Lednum,
graduate, on "Scientific Management." Mr. Lednum spoke of the
principles of Taylor and of Thompson, and told how these principles
were applied to the laying of the
sewerage system of Guilford. He
was employed on this work last
summer and gave several graphic
illustrations of practical scientific
management.
Abram Tobias was the second
speaker. His subject was hydroelectric development. After discussing the principles of location,
choice of turbines and generators,
and of transmission of large
amounts of electric energy, he
showed how these principles were
brought out in the construction of
the plant on the Patapsco at Ilchester, Md.
After a discussion ot the topics
presented by the speakers, in which
the members took part, the matter
of the formation of a collegiate
branch of the American Society of
Mechanical Engineers here at Hopkills was brought up by Dr. C. C.
Thomas, professor of mechanical
engineering. His proposition was
well received and was referred to
the Executive Committee slf the
Society with instructions to report
in the near future.
The attendance was very good.
Several of the engineering faculty
were present.
The next meeting will be held
March 5, at which time Messrs.
Evitt and Hutton will speak.

All the classes are eagerly looking forward to the annual class banquets, scheduled to come off this
month. These banquets will be of
great importance, especially to the
two lower classes, for "banquet
time" has always been a big event
for these two classes.
This year the freshmen are preparing to make their banquet a
howling success. The committee in
charge, consisting of Nelson, chairman; Egerton and Wolfe, are mapping out a line of campaign which
is to outdo any previous banquet of
like nature.
"Speakers will be had and many
distinguished men, who are enrolled
in the Class of 1918, will hold forth
to their less informed hearers," says
a member of the 1918 Committee.
The sophomores have also many
exciting plans laid. The sophomore
committee consists of Gorman, Fulton and Bin ford, and they have already undertaken the grave and
serious duties laid upon their shoulders. The seniors and juniors, upon
whom rest the dignity and prestige
of the University, have decided that
while their entertainments will be
joyous occasions, they will leave the
horse-play to the lower classes.
As a result of these deep-laid
schemes, the Johns Hopkins University and the City of Baltimore
will certainly witness some "gay
doings" this month.
The senior banquet committee
has not definitely chosen a date, but
the "feed" probably will be held on
the night of February 22 or 24.
